results.title: Australian Aborigines: cooking
results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Taken during the University of Sydney’s expedition to Arnhem Land, this film shows the traditional methods the local people use to cook food.

results.title: A Calendar of dreamings: Aboriginal artists of Central Australia
results.brief_description: This film depicts the mythology of First Nations people in the western McDonald Range area of Central Australia with specific reference to three tribal groups. It deals with ‘water dreaming’ as well as various myths and legends related to the present situation. The film incorporates approximately 44 paintings by Central Australia First Nations people using an ancient technique known as sand painting. A study of the meanings of the symbols and signs used in some paintings. Legends of the Dreamtime are passed down to the younger member by their elders in ritual ceremonies. Narrated by John Bell, edited by Phil Noyce.

results.title: Brown men and red sand
results.creator_credit: C Mountford and South Australian Government Tourist Bureau
results.brief_description: This film is part of the original silent film record of C.P. Mountford’s Central Australian journey with a group of desert First Nations people. From the original footage the two popular sound films, “Walkabout” and “Tjurunga”, were compiled. “Brown men and red sand” (if projected at silent speed) shows movement more naturally than in the sound films, where the movements look jerky (especially in the sequences dealing with ceremonies and dances).

results.title: Beyond hell's gate
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, Peter Johnson, Film Australia, Nomad Films and Satonyx Films
results.brief_description: Three trailbike riders retrace the route that led 15,000 Chinese and 1,500 Europeans from Cooktown through Hell’s Gate to the Palmer Goldfields of Northern Queensland. Partly dramatised, it recounts the coming of the Chinese, conflicts with local people and shows remnants of Maytown, the old mining settlement of Christie Palmerston, a legendary figure of the period.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Roberts, Peter Johnson, Film Australia, Nomad Films and Satonyx Films

results.title: Another day, another dollar: three short films about the history of work
results.brief_description:
“Projected memories: work in old films”: In 1947, a projectionist took a collection of instructional 16mm films about work to the bush. This short film includes excerpts from that collection covering early footage (1900s-1930s) of families on the land; factory workers; steel workers; coal miners; working women; the rise of trade-unions and the 8-hour day; peace campaign of 1938; the invention of the teleprinter; the arrival of the corner grocer shop and much more.
“Never done: women, work and history”: Focuses on women in the workplace from the mid-1800s through to the 1970s including footage of the first women’s union (1882); industrialisation and factory work; the birth of the modern office worker (1890s); equal pay for equal work movement; WWI and WWII women in the workforce; trade-unionism and feminism.
“Close to slavery: black work in white history”: It was government policy for First Nations peoples in Australia to assimilate to the white ethics of education and work. Then came the mission stations, removal of children, forced labour often in the most deplorable conditions, exploitation and even when First Nations Australians were trained in skilled work through the mission stations, white Australians would not employ them - all this most comprehensively portrayed by the archival footage in this film.

results.title: Dragon's Lair
results.brief_description: Dragon’s Lair looks more like a cartoon than a videogame. That’s because it was animated by Don Bluth, the legend behind The Land Before Time (1988), and its LaserDisc technology allowed for dramatically better graphics and sound than other games of the era.

constellations_primary.name: Dragon's Lair
constellations_primary.description: A look at pop-cultural interconnections that spawn from the lair of Don Bluth's arcade classic.

results.description:
Dragon’s Lair looks more like a cartoon than a videogame. There are two reasons for that: it was animated by legend Don Bluth, the man behind The Land Before Time (1988); and it used LaserDisc technology, allowing for dramatically better graphics and sound than other games released in 1983.

It was advertised as the first truly 3D videogame, but it maybe should’ve been advertised as the hardest videogame. Notorious for its difficulty, the gameplay features timed button/stick movements to advance the story and was deliberately designed to eat up as many coins as possible, even though it was already twice as expensive as typical games.

Despite the game being a little frustrating to casual players, Dragon’s Lair’s beautiful animation and unique gameplay means it has endured in pop-culture consciousness: it’s featured in many films and TV shows, including Family Guy (1999) and Stranger Things (2016).
description_for_label:

Notorious for its difficulty, the gameplay features timed button/stick movements to advance the story and was deliberately designed to eat up as many coins as possible, even though it was already twice as expensive as typical games.

Despite the game being a little frustrating to casual players, Dragon’s Lair’s beautiful animation and unique gameplay means it has endured in pop-culture consciousness: it’s featured in many films and TV shows, including Family Guy (1999) and Stranger Things (2016).

results.title: Escape from Woomera
results.brief_description: Escape from Woomera is a videogame that asks players to experience Australia’s draconian immigration policies from the point-of-view of a refugee. By combining game mechanics, art and activism, Escape from Woomera goes beyond the razor wire and detention centre media blackout.

constellations_other.name: Access to resistance
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

results.description:
If you thought escaping from Castle Wolfenstein was hard, try Woomera Immigration Reception and Processing Centre…

With a first person, 3D adventure game we invite gamers to assume the character of, and ‘live’ through the experiences of a modern day refugee. The effective media lock-out from immigration detention centres has meant that the whole truth about what goes on behind the razor-wire at Woomera, Baxter, Port Hedland, Maribyrnong and Villawood remains largely a mystery to the Australian public. We want to challenge this by offering the world a glimpse - more than that even: an interactive, immersive experience - of life within the most secretive and controversial places on the Australian political and geographical landscape. In this way, Escape From Woomera will be an engine for mobilising experiences and situations otherwise inaccessible to an nation of disempowered onlookers. It will provide both a portal and a toolkit for reworking and engaging with what is otherwise an entirely mediated current affair.

Lead artist/Environment artist: Stephen Honegger

Level designer: Ian Malcolm

Investigative journalist: Kate Wild

Cutscene artist: Morgan Simpson

Creative director: Katharine Neil

Animators: Andrea Blundell, Chris Markwart

Producers: Justin Halliday, Mark Angeli

Executive producer: Julian Oliver

Admin: Rani Kellock

Programming: Matthew Jones, David Jewsbury, Duncan Murray

Additional programming: Katharine Neil

UI art and website: Monique Jones

QA: Alex McNeilly

results.title: Vitaphone disc, "Wall Street", reel two
results.brief_description: Vitaphone was a sound film system used for feature films and nearly 1,000 short subjects made by Warner Bros. and its sister studio First National from 1926 to 1931. Vitaphone was the last major analog sound-on-disc system and the only one which was widely used and commercially successful.
